So with dysphagia it's like their brain lags behind when they try to initiate swallowing. That's when it becomes a problem, and their epiglottis doesn't cover their bronchial tube fast enough. This causes people aspirate. A person I worked with had to have moderately thick liquids, and they typically had thickened coffee, juice, and milk. Another person I worked with REFUSED to drink thickened water. The coffee might have been better warmed up when you tried it. Those that I've encountered that needed thickened liquids had to have their ice cream melted, then thickened, and refrozen before they could have it. Technically ice cream is a thin liquid when it melts.

My wife had to drink honey thick fluids after the came off the ventilator from COVID. She was having difficulties swallowing. The issue is asperating (inhaling) fluids when she swallowed. She is what they called silent aspirator - she could asperate on fluids and nobody would notice. The danger of asperating is that you lungs don't tolerate the foreign fluid and you could start an infection.  Once they did a couple of swallow test and she was not asperating anymore, the doctors took her to thinner and thinner fluids.

Thank u for doing this video! I have Severe Dysphagia so right now I'm NPO which means I can't have anything by mouth so everything goes through a feeding pump and feeding tube. When I was able to eat and drink, I had to use Thick-It to thicken my liquids to a honey consistency. U have to mix it very well in order to dissolve all the Thick-It. Once u mix it very well, u won't taste the Thick-It, except water, there will always be a taste to thickened water since regular thin water has no taste.
